abstract.p: Letter from New York Blood Center chairman, Howard Sloan, praises July 12 NYC column on shortage of blood in metropolitan area and exclusion of gays as donors; says it has given all blood collection agencies new opportunity to determine whether they can be less exclusionary without endangering general public

block.p: Re Clyde Haberman's July 12 NYC column, about the shortage of blood in the metropolitan area and the exclusion of gays as donors:
Re Clyde Haberman's July 12 NYC column, about the shortage of blood in the metropolitan area and the exclusion of gays as donors:

It is important for citizens to understand the difficult task the New York Blood Center faces in maximizing collections while protecting recipients. Every potential donor, whether heterosexual or gay, must fill out a questionnaire that can potentially exclude him or her from donating. Blood collection agencies need to be cautious, because there is a brief period of time between when an exclusionary disease like hepatitis is contracted and when it is reflected in a blood test.

What is the best way to balance public safety while being sensitive to an individual's privacy and lifestyle? By focusing widespread attention on this issue of elemental fairness, Mr. Haberman's column has given all blood collection agencies a new opportunity to determine whether we can be less exclusionary without endangering the general public.
HOWARD SLOAN Chairman, New York Blood Center New York, July 12, 2000
